title.narrative: Provision of trauma care through establishing first aid trauma posts (FATPs) to people in conflict affected districts in Herat province.

description.narrative: AADA is a non-political, non-profit, and independent national organization currently implementing BPHS and EPHS in Nangarhar and Ghazni and likewise BPHS in Herat province. AADA has wide range of experience in managing more than 17 humanitarian response projects funded by CHF/AHF, WHO, WFP and UNFPA over the past five years. The aim of the action is to support the existing three BHCs and one Health Sub-Center in Shindand, Pahstoon Kot, Gulran, and Khoshk-e- Robat Sangi districts of Herat in providing trauma care services to 79,107 people living in active conflict prone areas. The action will establish four fully functional First Aid Trauma Posts (FATPs) and four Rapid Response Teams (RRT) for conducting triage, transportation/referrals and build the capacity of the medical professionals in trauma initial management and basics of health response to Gender Based Violence (GBV) survivors and Psychosocial Support Services (PSS). The planned Heath Facilities (HFs) existing infrastructure will be enhanced through the construction of additional two rooms (one for male and one for female) to make them appropriately functional as FATPs. All FATPs will be equipped with medical and non-medical equipment and vehicles will be rented and equipped to serve as RRTs ambulances linked to four BHCs where the FATPs are established to ensure timely evacuation of war casualties from frontline to FATPs, then to nearest hospitals. FATPs will be staffed with two male and one female health professional (midwife/nurse) and RRT with one male nurse and will be trained on Basic Life Support (BLS) package, GBV response protocol and psychosocial counseling to provide trauma care, GBV cases initial management (identification, referrals and follow up) and counseling services to the population in needs to the target areas. To ensure project sustainability at least two BPHS paid staff (male and female) in each targeted HF will be trained on the above subjects to continue services delivery after the project conclusion. The project implementation will be carried out in close coordination with the Provincial Public Health Directorate (PPHD), regional health cluster, and other stakeholders including communities and groups involved in different locations in the province.
